header_summary:
Ava Chow announced the release of Bitcoin Core version 28.1, introducing new features, bug fixes, and performance improvements, with detailed guidance for upgrading from older versions and compatibility information across various operating systems. This update, available for download from [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.1), also makes specific adjustments to peer-to-peer configurations to enhance usability and reduce startup failures. Significant changes include internal ID counting updates, enhancements in key handling, build system improvements, and a call for community participation in reporting bugs and joining the announcement list.

Jameson Lopp raised concerns about the reliability of timestamp data in Bitcoin transactions, specifically the vulnerability of the nLockTime feature to manipulation by adversaries for unfair prioritization benefits. This flaw could lead to a "race to the bottom," undermining the effectiveness of new prioritization rules, highlighting the need for further deliberation on securing transaction timestamp integrity within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List. The discussion underscores potential vulnerabilities in the proposed system and stimulates further exploration of securing transaction integrity ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/f1a0153b-3142-4e01-a68e-92c458762b89@dashjr.org/T/#md45faf348c4d6ff9b7a87019770ad6967382bd2a)).

Yuval Kogman critiqued the misconceptions around privacy mechanisms in blockchain technology, focusing on the limitations and vulnerabilities of wabisabi credentials and the Wasabi wallet's implementation. The discourse reveals significant oversight in privacy and security auditing, highlighting the complexity of achieving comprehensive privacy protections and the ethical implications of exploiting users' privacy for profit. Kogman's analysis sheds light on the challenges in safeguarding privacy and security, emphasizing the importance of transparency, comprehensive security measures, and ethical considerations in the development of privacy-preserving technologies ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAAQdECAg5W4a9_386FeGWBZnv7zje4gmXtAMcC8scWq_o2dEwg@mail.gmail.com/T/#mc443b9fe5281ff0e052fbf07ef8658cb9f58e8b3)).

Antoine Riard announced plans to take legal action against Matthew Corallo over governance and respect issues within open-source software projects, underlining a fundamental disagreement between the two contributors. The dispute, rooted in differing views on leadership and contributions, has led Riard to seek judicial resolution to prevent misrepresentation and manipulation, emphasizing the broader implications for open-source project governance and the interpretation of decentralization ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/code-of-conduct-violation-banning-antoine-riard-for-3-months/1254/3)).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.1 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 28.1 is now available, featuring new enhancements and bug fixes.
- The update supports Linux Kernel 3.17+, macOS 11.0+, and Windows 7 or newer, with specific macOS self-signing instructions.
- Significant changes include P2P configuration adjustments and improvements in addrman ID counting and key handling.

- It emphasizes the significance of full node support checks and potential solutions for privacy.

recent_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
recent_posts.summary:
- The evolution in blockchain change implementation moves from DASK to soft forks, avoiding new addresses.
- Matt Corallo proposes disabling P2TR key-spending and using `OP_SUCCESS` for post-quantum signatures.
- Corallo's method seeks community consensus on hash signatures, aiming for a quantum-resistant soft fork.

recent_posts.title: Code of Conduct Violation: Banning Antoine Riard for 3 months
recent_posts.summary:
- Antoine Riard is suing Matthew Corallo, potentially in North Carolina, over rust-lightning project disputes.
- Riard aims to stop alleged misrepresentation and manipulation by Corallo, stressing the conflict is within OSS governance, not US security.
- He advocates for legal resolution to OSS disputes, prepared to take it to the Supreme Court if needed.

recent_posts.title: Deterministic tx selection for censorship resistance
recent_posts.summary:
- Braidpool is a decentralized network similar to Bitcoin, challenging in decision-making.
- Upgrading nodes and the potential for a hard fork in the DAG highlight management challenges.
- There is a proposal for miners to include limited non-committed bitcoin transactions for flexibility.

today_in_history_posts.title: Proof-of-Stake Bitcoin Sidechains
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The writer proposes a design for a proof-of-mainstake sidechain without altering Bitcoin's mainchain.
- They suggest embedding the sidechain block headers in the mainchain through specific transactions authorized by stakers.
- Mainchain-to-sidechain indications for staking or transferring coins involve a special UTXO script, enhancing transaction management.

today_in_history_posts.title: Lightning and the semantic web
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Melvin is integrating the Lightning Network with Solid through ontology creation.
- He seeks existing work on ontology in this area or collaboration opportunities.
- Solid enhances user data control; Lightning Network quickens Bitcoin transactions.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive and active investments are two distinct strategies with varying levels of involvement.
- Issues with passive investment include the principal/agent problem and potential societal impacts.
- The article suggests central banks could stabilize economies using a blend of inflationary and deflationary currencies.
